newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU probing software distribution practices.
newsitem.headline: EU probing software distribution practices.

text.p: The European Union's competition chief, Karel Van Miert, said Wednesday he was investigating complaints of anti-competitive software distribution practices in the EU.
"We are looking into some of these cases," he said at a news conference.

Despite repeated questions, Van Miert refused to give any details. But he has previously said the European Commission was investigating a complaint about the pricing practices of U.S. software giant Microsoft Corp.
That complaint was filed more than a year ago by the Personal Computer Association in Britain, which said Wednesday it was getting impatient for results.

The association charges Microsoft with abusing its dominant position in its pricing practices, when selling the MS Office software package to personal computer manufacturers who want to "bundle" it into the machines they sell.
It says Microsoft charges a handful of key customers, including U.S. computer maker Gateway 2000, much lower prices than it charges the rest of its customers.
"The result of this is that Microsoft as a monopoly supplier is restricting the availability of a monopoly product," PCA executive director Keith Warburton said.
